text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- King Hussein meets U.N. Secretary-General in New York and calls for comprehensive peace and an end to suffering of Iraqi people.
- Jordan cancels meeting with Israel, scheduled to have been held by end-March, to discuss building of joint "peace airport" in Aqaba, officials say.

- King Hussein to discuss Middle East peace and Iraq with U.S. President Clinton today. Sources say Jordan seeks $2 billion in loans and hopes the United States can persuade other creditors to cancel its debts. Jordan is also following up World Bank offer of $1 billion in next five years to help economic and social programmes, and seeking more U.S. military aid.
- New Foreign Minister Fayez al-Tarawneh, formerly ambassador to Washington, sworn in by King Hussein.
- Opposition parties reject "one-man-one-vote" parliamentary voting law and say voting cards should be distributed free.
- Investigation into shooting of Israeli schoolgirls expected to continue until after Moslem Feast of Eid al-Adha in late April and soldier won't be charged before then, sources say.

- King Hussein to warn Clinton of the danger of letting crisis in West Bank continue. Discussion of proposals for resuming Palestinian-Israeli negotiations and speeding up final negotiations. Jordan's economic needs for the next year also to be discussed.
- Palestinian refugee camps in Jordan will be included in financial support provided by social safety net.
- Parliamentary committee formed to study bread prices recommended reduction to 150 fils (21 U.S. cents) a kilo, but government refused it because of instability in world wheat prices.
- King holds talks with Annan, due to meet Clinton today.
- Israeli ambassador's car attacked in Jordan.
- Jordanian and Iraqi businessmen agree to expand trade cooperation.
